applicationLoadBalancerUpdateAccessLoggi.description:
Configure access logging for the load balancer.

Elastic Load Balancing provides access logs that capture
detailed information about requests sent to your load
balancer. Each log contains information such as the time the
request was received, the client's IP address, latencies,
request paths, and server responses. You can use these
access logs to analyze traffic patterns and troubleshoot
issues.

instanceUpdateMetadataService.title: Update Metadata Service
instanceUpdateMetadataService.description:
Instance metadata is data about your instance that you can use to configure or manage the running instance.
Instance metadata is divided into categories, for example, host name, events, and security groups.

Instance metadata can be accessed from a running instance using one of the following methods:

  Instance Metadata Service Version 1 (IMDSv1)  a request/response method

  Instance Metadata Service Version 2 (IMDSv2)  a session-oriented method

By default, you can use either IMDSv1 or IMDSv2, or both. However, the instance metadata service can be specifically
configured to use IMDSv2 on each instance. When you specify that IMDSv2 must be used, IMDSv1 no longer works.

amiActive.title: Active
amiActive.description:
Take an action when an AWS EC2 ami is not active based on the
`AWS > EC2 > AMI > Active > *` policies.

The Active control determines whether the resource is in active use, and if not, has
the ability to delete / cleanup the resource. When running an automated compliance
environment, it's common to end up with a wide range of alarms that are difficult
and time consuming to clear. The Active control brings automated, well-defined
control to this process.

The Active control checks the status of all defined Active policies for the
resource (`AWS > EC2 > AMI > Active > *`),
raises an alarm, and takes the defined enforcement action. Each Active
sub-policy can calculate a status of active, inactive or skipped. Generally,
if the resource appears to be Active for any reason it will be considered Active.

Note the contrast with Approved, where if the resource appears to be Unapproved
for any reason it will be considered Unapproved.

See [Active](https://turbot.com/v5/docs/concepts/guardrails/active) for more information.

amiApproved.title: Approved
amiApproved.description:
Take an action when an AWS EC2 ami is not approved based on `AWS > EC2 > AMI > Approved > * policies`.

The Approved control checks the status of the defined Approved sub-policies for the resource. If the resource is not approved according to any of these policies, this control raises an alarm and takes the defined enforcement action.

For any enforcement actions that specify `if new`, e.g., `Enforce: Delete unapproved if new`, this control will only take the enforcement actions for resources created within the last 60 minutes.

See [Approved](https://turbot.com/v5/docs/concepts/guardrails/approved) for more information.

precheck.reason: CMDB control is in TBD state

amiCmdb.title: CMDB
amiCmdb.description:
Record and synchronize details for the AWS EC2 ami into the CMDB.

The [CMDB](https://turbot.com/v5/docs/concepts/guardrails/cmdb) control is responsible for populating and updating all the attributes for that resource type in the Turbot CMDB.

If set to Skip then all changes to the CMDB are paused - no new resources will be discovered, no updates will be made and deleted resources will not be removed.

To cleanup resources and stop tracking changes, set this policy to **"Enforce: Disabled"**.

CMDB controls also use the Regions policy associated with the resource. If region is not in `AWS > EC2 > AMI > Regions` policy, the CMDB control will delete the resource from the CMDB. (**Note**: Setting CMDB to Skip will also pause these changes.)

amiConfigured.title: Configured
amiConfigured.description:
Maintain AWS > EC2 > AMI configuration

**Note**: If the resource is managed by another stack, then the Skip/Check/Enforce values here are ignored
and inherit from the stack that owns it

amiDiscovery.title: Discovery
amiDiscovery.description:
Discover all AWS EC2 ami resources and add them to the CMDB.

The [Discovery](https://turbot.com/v5/docs/concepts/guardrails/discovery) control is responsible for finding resources of a specific type. It periodically searches for new resources and saves them to the CMDB. Once discovered, resources are then responsible for tracking changes to themselves through the [CMDB](https://turbot.com/v5/docs/concepts/guardrails/cmdb) control.

Note that Discovery and CMDB controls also use the Regions policy associated with the resource. If the region is not in `AWS > EC2 > AMI > Regions` policy, the CMDB control will delete the resource from the CMDB.

amiTags.title: Tags
amiTags.description:
Take an action when an AWS EC2 ami tags is not updated based on the `AWS > EC2 > AMI > Tags > * policies`.

If the resource is not updated with the tags defined in `AWS > EC2 > AMI > Tags > Template`, this control raises an alarm and takes the defined enforcement action.

See [Tags](https://turbot.com/v5/docs/concepts/guardrails/tagging) for more information.

amiTrustedAccess.title: Trusted Access
amiTrustedAccess.description:
Manage trusted access for AWS EC2 AMIs.

AWS allows EC2 AMIs to be shared with specific AWS accounts.
This control allows you to configure whether such sharing is allowed, and to which accounts.

If set to `Enforce`, access to non-trusted accounts will be removed.

precheck.reason: CMDB control is in TBD state

amiUsage.title: Usage
amiUsage.description:
The Usage control determines whether the number of AWS EC2 ami resources exceeds the configured usage limit for this region.

You can configure the behavior of this control with the  `AWS > EC2 > AMI > Usage` policy, and set the limit with the `AWS > EC2 > AMI > Usage > Limit` policy.

Take an action when an AWS EC2 application load balancer tags is not updated based on the `AWS > EC2 > Application Load Balancer > Tags > * policies`.

If the resource is not updated with the tags defined in `AWS > EC2 > Application Load Balancer > Tags > Template`, this control raises an alarm and takes the defined enforcement action.

See [Tags](https://turbot.com/v5/docs/concepts/guardrails/tagging) for more information.

applicationLoadBalancerUsage.title: Usage
applicationLoadBalancerUsage.description:
The Usage control determines whether the number of AWS EC2 application load balancer resources exceeds the configured usage limit for this region.

You can configure the behavior of this control with the  `AWS > EC2 > Application Load Balancer > Usage` policy, and set the limit with the `AWS > EC2 > Application Load Balancer > Usage > Limit` policy.

autoScalingGroupActive.title: Active
autoScalingGroupActive.description:
Take an action when an AWS EC2 auto scaling group is not active based on the
`AWS > EC2 > Auto Scaling Group > Active > *` policies.

The Active control determines whether the resource is in active use, and if not, has
the ability to delete / cleanup the resource. When running an automated compliance
environment, it's common to end up with a wide range of alarms that are difficult
and time consuming to clear. The Active control brings automated, well-defined
control to this process.

The Active control checks the status of all defined Active policies for the
resource (`AWS > EC2 > Auto Scaling Group > Active > *`),
raises an alarm, and takes the defined enforcement action. Each Active
sub-policy can calculate a status of active, inactive or skipped. Generally,
if the resource appears to be Active for any reason it will be considered Active.

Note the contrast with Approved, where if the resource appears to be Unapproved
for any reason it will be considered Unapproved.

See [Active](https://turbot.com/v5/docs/concepts/guardrails/active) for more information.

autoScalingGroupApproved.title: Approved
autoScalingGroupApproved.description:
Take an action when an AWS EC2 auto scaling group is not approved based on `AWS > EC2 > Auto Scaling Group > Approved > * policies`.

The Approved control checks the status of the defined Approved sub-policies for the resource. If the resource is not approved according to any of these policies, this control raises an alarm and takes the defined enforcement action.

For any enforcement actions that specify `if new`, e.g., `Enforce: Delete unapproved if new`, this control will only take the enforcement actions for resources created within the last 60 minutes.

See [Approved](https://turbot.com/v5/docs/concepts/guardrails/approved) for more information.

precheck.reason: CMDB control is in TBD state

autoScalingGroupCmdb.title: CMDB
autoScalingGroupCmdb.description:
Record and synchronize details for the AWS EC2 auto scaling group into the CMDB.

The [CMDB](https://turbot.com/v5/docs/concepts/guardrails/cmdb) control is responsible for populating and updating all the attributes for that resource type in the Turbot CMDB.

If set to Skip then all changes to the CMDB are paused - no new resources will be discovered, no updates will be made and deleted resources will not be removed.

To cleanup resources and stop tracking changes, set this policy to **"Enforce: Disabled"**.

CMDB controls also use the Regions policy associated with the resource. If region is not in `AWS > EC2 > Auto Scaling Group > Regions` policy, the CMDB control will delete the resource from the CMDB. (**Note**: Setting CMDB to Skip will also pause these changes.)

autoScalingGroupDiscovery.title: Discovery
autoScalingGroupDiscovery.description:
Discover all AWS EC2 auto scaling group resources and add them to the CMDB.

The [Discovery](https://turbot.com/v5/docs/concepts/guardrails/discovery) control is responsible for finding resources of a specific type. It periodically searches for new resources and saves them to the CMDB. Once discovered, resources are then responsible for tracking changes to themselves through the [CMDB](https://turbot.com/v5/docs/concepts/guardrails/cmdb) control.

Note that Discovery and CMDB controls also use the Regions policy associated with the resource. If the region is not in `AWS > EC2 > Auto Scaling Group > Regions` policy, the CMDB control will delete the resource from the CMDB.

classicLoadBalancerAccessLogging.title: Access Logging
classicLoadBalancerAccessLogging.description:
Define the Access Logging settings required for `AWS > EC2 > Classic Load Balancer`.

`AWS > EC2 > Classic Load Balancer` provides access logs that capture
detailed information about requests sent to your load
balancer. Each log contains information such as the time the
request was received, the client's IP address, latencies,
request paths, and server responses. You can use these
access logs to analyze traffic patterns and troubleshoot
issues.

instanceDetailedMonitoring.title: Detailed Monitoring
instanceDetailedMonitoring.description:
Define the Detailed Monitoring settings required for `AWS > EC2 > Instance > Detailed Monitoring`.

If detailed monitoring is enabled then Amazon EC2 console displays monitoring graphs with a 1-minute period for the instance.

**Note**: Enabling detailed monitoring will incur additional charges.

instanceInstanceProfile.title: Instance Profile
instanceInstanceProfile.description: Determine whether the IAM instance profile is attached to instance.

instanceMetadataService.title: Metadata Service
instanceMetadataService.description:
Instance metadata is data about your instance that you can use to configure or manage the running instance.
Instance metadata is divided into categories, for example, host name, events, and security groups.

Instance metadata can be accessed from a running instance using one of the following methods:

  * Instance Metadata Service Version 1 (IMDSv1)  a request/response method

  * Instance Metadata Service Version 2 (IMDSv2)  a session-oriented method

By default, you can use either IMDSv1 or IMDSv2, or both. However, the instance metadata service can be specifically
configured to use IMDSv2 on each instance. When you specify that IMDSv2 must be used, IMDSv1 no longer works.

instanceSchedule.title: Schedule
instanceSchedule.description:
Set a schedule for starting and stopping an AWS EC2 instance.

**Note** If both "Schedule" and "Schedule Tag" are set to enforce and the
instance has a turbot_custom_schedule tag, then the schedule specified by
the tag will be in effect.

Record and synchronize details for the AWS EC2 listener rule into the CMDB.

The [CMDB](https://turbot.com/v5/docs/concepts/guardrails/cmdb) control is responsible for populating and updating all the attributes for that resource type in the Turbot CMDB.

If set to Skip then all changes to the CMDB are paused - no new resources will be discovered, no updates will be made and deleted resources will not be removed.

To cleanup resources and stop tracking changes, set this policy to **"Enforce: Disabled"**.

CMDB controls also use the Regions policy associated with the resource. If region is not in `AWS > EC2 > Listener Rule > Regions` policy, the CMDB control will delete the resource from the CMDB. (**Note**: Setting CMDB to Skip will also pause these changes.)

listenerRuleConfigured.title: Configured
listenerRuleConfigured.description:
Maintain AWS > EC2 > Listener Rule configuration

**Note**: If the resource is managed by another stack, then the Skip/Check/Enforce values here are ignored
and inherit from the stack that owns it

listenerRuleDiscovery.title: Discovery
listenerRuleDiscovery.description:
Discover all AWS EC2 listener rule resources and add them to the CMDB.

The [Discovery](https://turbot.com/v5/docs/concepts/guardrails/discovery) control is responsible for finding resources of a specific type. It periodically searches for new resources and saves them to the CMDB. Once discovered, resources are then responsible for tracking changes to themselves through the [CMDB](https://turbot.com/v5/docs/concepts/guardrails/cmdb) control.

Note that Discovery and CMDB controls also use the Regions policy associated with the resource. If the region is not in `AWS > EC2 > Listener Rule > Regions` policy, the CMDB control will delete the resource from the CMDB.

listenerRuleUsage.title: Usage
listenerRuleUsage.description:
The Usage control determines whether the number of AWS EC2 listener rule resources exceeds the configured usage limit for this applicationLoadBalancer.

You can configure the behavior of this control with the  `AWS > EC2 > Listener Rule > Usage` policy, and set the limit with the `AWS > EC2 > Listener Rule > Usage > Limit` policy.

classicLoadBalancerListenerActive.title: Active
classicLoadBalancerListenerActive.description:
Take an action when an AWS EC2 classic load balancer listener is not active based on the
`AWS > EC2 > Classic Load Balancer Listener > Active > *` policies.

The Active control determines whether the resource is in active use, and if not, has
the ability to delete / cleanup the resource. When running an automated compliance
environment, it's common to end up with a wide range of alarms that are difficult
and time consuming to clear. The Active control brings automated, well-defined
control to this process.

The Active control checks the status of all defined Active policies for the
resource (`AWS > EC2 > Classic Load Balancer Listener > Active > *`),
raises an alarm, and takes the defined enforcement action. Each Active
sub-policy can calculate a status of active, inactive or skipped. Generally,
if the resource appears to be Active for any reason it will be considered Active.

Note the contrast with Approved, where if the resource appears to be Unapproved
for any reason it will be considered Unapproved.

See [Active](https://turbot.com/v5/docs/concepts/guardrails/active) for more information.

classicLoadBalancerListenerApproved.title: Approved
classicLoadBalancerListenerApproved.description:
Take an action when an AWS EC2 classic load balancer listener is not approved based on `AWS > EC2 > Classic Load Balancer Listener > Approved > * policies`.

The Approved control checks the status of the defined Approved sub-policies for the resource. If the resource is not approved according to any of these policies, this control raises an alarm and takes the defined enforcement action.

For any enforcement actions that specify `if new`, e.g., `Enforce: Delete unapproved if new`, this control will only take the enforcement actions for resources created within the last 60 minutes.

See [Approved](https://turbot.com/v5/docs/concepts/guardrails/approved) for more information.

classicLoadBalancerListenerSslPolicy.title: SSL Policy
classicLoadBalancerListenerSslPolicy.description:
Take an action when an AWS EC2 classic load balancer listener is not using an allowed SSL policy.

If the SSL policy specified in the `AWS > EC2 > Classic Load Balancer Listener > SSL Policy > Default` policy is not in the `AWS > EC2 > Classic Load Balancer Listener > SSL Policy > Allowed` policy, the control will move to `invalid` to prevent a conflict.

Scheme.description: The nodes of an Internet-facing load balancer have public IP addresses. amiActive.title: Active
amiActive.description:
Determine the action to take when an AWS EC2 ami, based on the `AWS > EC2 > AMI > Active > *` policies.

The control determines whether the resource is in active use, and if not,
has the ability to delete / cleanup the resource. When running an automated
compliance environment, it's common to end up with a wide range of alarms
that are difficult and time consuming to clear. The Active control brings
automated, well-defined control to this process.

The Active control checks the status of all defined Active policies for the
resource (`AWS > EC2 > AMI > Active > *`), raises an alarm, and takes the defined enforcement
action. Each Active sub-policy can calculate a status of active, inactive
or skipped. Generally, if the resource appears to be Active for any reason
it will be considered Active.
**Note** the contrast with Approved, where if the resource appears to be Unapproved for any reason it will be considered
Unapproved.

See [Active](https://turbot.com/v5/docs/concepts/guardrails/active) for more information.

enum: Enforce: Delete inactive with 1 day warning
Enforce: Delete inactive with 3 days warning
Enforce: Delete inactive with 7 days warning
Enforce: Delete inactive with 14 days warning
Enforce: Delete inactive with 30 days warning
Enforce: Delete inactive with 60 days warning
Enforce: Delete inactive with 90 days warning
Enforce: Delete inactive with 180 days warning
Enforce: Delete inactive with 365 days warning

amiActiveLastModified.description:

was last modified before it is considered inactive.

the ability to delete / cleanup the resource. When running an automated

if the resource appears to be Active for any reason it will be considered Active.
**Note** the contrast with Approved, where if the resource appears to be Unapproved
for any reason it will be considered Unapproved.

See [Active](https://turbot.com/v5/docs/concepts/guardrails/active) for more information.

enum: Force active if last modified <= 1 day
Force active if last modified <= 3 days
Force active if last modified <= 7 days
Force active if last modified <= 14 days
Force active if last modified <= 30 days
Force active if last modified <= 60 days
Force active if last modified <= 90 days
Force active if last modified <= 180 days
Force active if last modified <= 365 days

is no longer considered active. If a create time is unavailable, the time Turbot discovered the resource is used.

The [Active](https://turbot.com/v5/docs/concepts/guardrails/active)
control determines whether the resource is in active use, and if not, has
the ability to delete / cleanup the resource. When running an automated

**Note** the contrast with Approved, where if the resource appears to be Unapproved

See [Active](https://turbot.com/v5/docs/concepts/guardrails/active) for more information.

amiActiveBudget.title: Budget
amiActiveBudget.description:
The impact of the budget state on the active control. This policy allows you to force
amis to inactive based on the current budget state, as reflected in
`AWS > Account > Budget > State`

The Active control determines whether the resource is in active use, and if not, has
the ability to delete / cleanup the resource. When running an automated compliance
environment, it's common to end up with a wide range of alarms that are difficult
and time consuming to clear. The Active control brings automated, well-defined
control to this process.

**Note** the contrast with Approved, where if the resource appears to be Unapproved
for any reason it will be considered Unapproved.

See [Active](https://turbot.com/v5/docs/concepts/guardrails/active) for more information.

enum: Force inactive if Budget > State is Over or higher
Force inactive if Budget > State is Critical or higher
Force inactive if Budget > State is Shutdown

amiApproved.title: Approved
amiApproved.description:
Determine the action to take when an AWS EC2 ami is not approved based on `AWS > EC2 > AMI > Approved > *` policies.

The Approved control checks the status of the defined Approved sub-policies for the resource. If the resource is not approved according to any of these policies, this control raises an alarm and takes the defined enforcement action.

For any enforcement actions that specify `if new`, e.g., `Enforce: Delete unapproved if new`, this control will only take the enforcement actions for resources created within the last 60 minutes.

See [Approved](https://turbot.com/v5/docs/concepts/guardrails/approved) for more information.

amiApprovedRegions.title: Regions
amiApprovedRegions.description:
A list of AWS regions in which AWS EC2 amis are approved for use.

The expected format is an array of regions names. You may use the '*' and '?' wildcard characters.

This policy will be evaluated by the Approved control. If an AWS EC2 ami is created in a region that is not in the approved list, it will be subject to the action specified in the `AWS > EC2 > AMI > Approved` policy.

See [Approved](https://turbot.com/v5/docs/concepts/guardrails/approved) for more information.
amiApprovedRegions.defaultTemplate:
{% if $.regions | length == 0 %} [] {% endif %}{% for item in $.regions %}- '{{ item }}'
{% endfor %}

amiApprovedUsage.title: Usage
amiApprovedUsage.description:
Determine whether the AWS EC2 ami is allowed to exist.

This policy will be evaluated by the Approved control. If an AWS EC2 ami is not approved, it will be subject to the action specified in the `AWS > EC2 > AMI > Approved` policy.

See [Approved](https://turbot.com/v5/docs/concepts/guardrails/approved) for more information.

amiApprovedBudget.title: Budget
amiApprovedBudget.description:
The policy allows you to set amis to unapproved based on the current budget state, as reflected in `AWS > Account > Budget > State`

This policy will be evaluated by the Approved control. If an AWS EC2 ami is not matched by the approved list, it will be subject to the action specified in the `AWS > EC2 > AMI > Approved` policy.

See [Approved](https://turbot.com/v5/docs/concepts/guardrails/approved) for more information.

enum: Unapproved if Budget > State is Over or higher
Unapproved if Budget > State is Critical or higher
Unapproved if Budget > State is Shutdown
example: Unapproved if Budget > State is Shutdown

amiCmdb.title: CMDB
amiCmdb.description:
Configure whether to record and synchronize details for the AWS EC2 ami into the CMDB.

The [CMDB](https://turbot.com/v5/docs/concepts/guardrails/cmdb) control is responsible for populating and updating all the attributes for that resource type in the Turbot CMDB.
All policies and controls in Turbot are based around the resource, so usually the CMDB policy is set to **"Enforce: Enabled"**.

If set to Skip then all changes to the CMDB are paused - no new resources will be discovered, no updates will be made and deleted resources will not be removed.

To cleanup resources and stop tracking changes, set this policy to **"Enforce: Disabled"**.

CMDB controls also use the Regions policy associated with the resource. If region is not in `AWS > EC2 > AMI > Regions` policy, the CMDB control will delete the resource from the CMDB.

(**Note**: Setting CMDB to **"Skip"** will also pause these changes.)

amiConfigured.title: Configured
amiConfigured.description:
Determine how to configure this resource.

**Note**: If the resource is managed by another stack, then the Skip/Check/Enforce values here are ignored
and inherit from the stack that owns it

enum: Check: Per Configured > Source (unless claimed by a stack)
Enforce: Per Configured > Source (unless claimed by a stack)

amiConfiguredSource.title: Source
amiConfiguredSource.description: A HCL or JSON format Terraform configuration source used to configure this resource

amiConfiguredPrecedence.title: Claim Precedence
amiConfiguredPrecedence.description:
An ordered list of who is allowed to claim a resource.
A stack cannot claim a resource if it is already claimed by another
stack at a higher level of precedence.
amiConfiguredPrecedence.defaultTemplate: {%- if $.defaultPrecedence | length == 0 %}[]{%- else %}{% for item in $.defaultPrecedence %}- '{{ item }}'{% endfor %}{% endif %}

amiRegions.title: Regions
amiRegions.description:
A list of AWS regions in which AWS EC2 amis are supported for use.

Any amis in a region not listed here will not be recorded in CMDB.

The expected format is an array of regions names. You may use the '*' and
'?' wildcard characters.
amiRegions.defaultTemplate:
{% if $.regions.value | length == 0 %} [] {% endif %}{% for item in $.regions.value %}- '{{ item }}'
{% endfor %}

amiTags.title: Tags
amiTags.description:
Determine the action to take when an AWS EC2 ami tags are not updated based on the `AWS > EC2 > AMI > Tags > *` policies.

The control ensure AWS EC2 ami tags include tags defined in `AWS > EC2 > AMI > Tags > Template`.

Tags not defined in AMI Tags Template will not be modified or deleted. Setting a tag value to `undefined` will result in the tag being deleted.

See [Tags](https://turbot.com/v5/docs/concepts/guardrails/tagging) for more information.

amiTagsTemplate.title: Template
amiTagsTemplate.description:
The template is used to generate the keys and values for AWS EC2 ami.

Tags not defined in AMI Tags Template will not be modified or deleted. Setting a tag value to `undefined` will result in the tag being deleted.

See [Tags](https://turbot.com/v5/docs/concepts/guardrails/tagging) for more information.
amiTagsTemplate.defaultTemplate: {%- if $.defaultTags.value | length == 0 %} [] {%- elif $.defaultTags.value != undefined %}{{ $.defaultTags.value | dump | safe }}{%- else %}{% for item in $.defaultTags.value %}- {{ item }}{% endfor %}{% endif %}

amiTrustedAccess.title: Trusted Access
amiTrustedAccess.description:
Manage trusted access for AWS EC2 AMIs.

AWS allows EC2 AMIs to be shared with specific AWS accounts.
This policy allows you to configure whether such sharing is allowed, and to which accounts.

If set to `Enforce`, access to non-trusted accounts will be removed.

amiTrustedAccessAccounts.title: Accounts
amiTrustedAccessAccounts.description: A list of AWS account IDs that are allowed to have access
amiTrustedAccessAccounts.defaultTemplate:
{% if $.accounts | length == 0 %}[]{% endif %}{% for item in $.accounts %}- '{{ item }}'
{% endfor %}

amiUsage.title: Usage
amiUsage.description:
Configure the number of AWS EC2 amis that can be used for this region and the current consumption against the limit.

You can configure the behavior of the control with this  `AWS > EC2 > AMI > Usage` policy.

amiUsageLimit.title: Limit
amiUsageLimit.description: Maximum number of items that can be created for this region.

applicationLoadBalancerAccessLogging.title: Access Logging
applicationLoadBalancerAccessLogging.description:
Define the Access Logging settings required for `AWS > EC2 > Application Load Balancer`.

`AWS > EC2 > Application Load Balancer` provides access logs that capture
detailed information about requests sent to your load
balancer. Each log contains information such as the time the
request was received, the client's IP address, latencies,
request paths, and server responses. You can use these
access logs to analyze traffic patterns and troubleshoot
issues.

enum: Check: Enabled to Access Logging > Bucket
Enforce: Enabled to Access Logging > Bucket

applicationLoadBalancerAccessLoggingBuck.title: Bucket
applicationLoadBalancerAccessLoggingBuck.description:
The name of an S3 Bucket to which the Bucket
access logs will be delivered.

The S3 Bucket must already exist and the S3 service must be allowed write access.
The bucket can reside in any account but must be in the same region as the Load Balancer.

example:
```
  testbucket
  turbotbucket
```

applicationLoadBalancerAccessLoggingKeyP.title: Key Prefix
applicationLoadBalancerAccessLoggingKeyP.description:
An optional S3 key prefix to which the `AWS > EC2 > Application Load Balancer` access logs will be written.

The file names of the access logs use the following format:
`bucket[/prefix]/AWSLogs/aws-account-id/elasticloadbalancing/region/yyyy/mm/dd/aws-account-id_elasticloadbalancing_region_load-balancer-id_end-time_ip-address_random-string.log.gz`

The [Active](https://turbot.com/v5/docs/concepts/guardrails/active)
control determines whether the resource is in active use, and if not, has
the ability to delete / cleanup the resource. When running an automated
compliance environment, it's common to end up with a wide range of alarms
that are difficult and time consuming to clear. The Active control brings
automated, well-defined control to this process.

The Active control checks the status of all defined Active policies for the
resource (`AWS > EC2 > Application Load Balancer > Active > *`),
raises an alarm, and takes the defined enforcement action. Each Active
sub-policy can calculate a status of active, inactive or skipped. Generally,
if the resource appears to be Active for any reason it will be considered Active.
**Note** the contrast with Approved, where if the resource appears to be Unapproved
for any reason it will be considered Unapproved.

See [Active](https://turbot.com/v5/docs/concepts/guardrails/active) for more information.

applicationLoadBalancerActiveBudget.title: Budget
applicationLoadBalancerActiveBudget.description:
The impact of the budget state on the active control. This policy allows you to force
applicationLoadBalancers to inactive based on the current budget state, as reflected in
`AWS > Account > Budget > State`

enum: Force inactive if Budget > State is Over or higher
Force inactive if Budget > State is Critical or higher
Force inactive if Budget > State is Shutdown

applicationLoadBalancerApproved.title: Approved
applicationLoadBalancerApproved.description:
Determine the action to take when an AWS EC2 application load balancer is not approved based on `AWS > EC2 > Application Load Balancer > Approved > *` policies.

The Approved control checks the status of the defined Approved sub-policies for the resource. If the resource is not approved according to any of these policies, this control raises an alarm and takes the defined enforcement action.

For any enforcement actions that specify `if new`, e.g., `Enforce: Delete unapproved if new`, this control will only take the enforcement actions for resources created within the last 60 minutes.

See [Approved](https://turbot.com/v5/docs/concepts/guardrails/approved) for more information.

applicationLoadBalancerApprovedRegions.title: Regions
applicationLoadBalancerApprovedRegions.description:
A list of AWS regions in which AWS EC2 application load balancers are approved for use.

The expected format is an array of regions names. You may use the '*' and '?' wildcard characters.

This policy will be evaluated by the Approved control. If an AWS EC2 application load balancer is created in a region that is not in the approved list, it will be subject to the action specified in the `AWS > EC2 > Application Load Balancer > Approved` policy.

See [Approved](https://turbot.com/v5/docs/concepts/guardrails/approved) for more information.
applicationLoadBalancerApprovedRegions.defaultTemplate:
{% if $.regions | length == 0 %} [] {% endif %}{% for item in $.regions %}- '{{ item }}'
{% endfor %}

applicationLoadBalancerApprovedUsage.title: Usage
applicationLoadBalancerApprovedUsage.description:
Determine whether the AWS EC2 application load balancer is allowed to exist.

This policy will be evaluated by the Approved control. If an AWS EC2 application load balancer is not approved, it will be subject to the action specified in the `AWS > EC2 > Application Load Balancer > Approved` policy.

See [Approved](https://turbot.com/v5/docs/concepts/guardrails/approved) for more information.

applicationLoadBalancerApprovedBudget.title: Budget
applicationLoadBalancerApprovedBudget.description:
The policy allows you to set application load balancers to unapproved based on the current budget state, as reflected in `AWS > Account > Budget > State`

This policy will be evaluated by the Approved control. If an AWS EC2 application load balancer is not matched by the approved list, it will be subject to the action specified in the `AWS > EC2 > Application Load Balancer > Approved` policy.

See [Approved](https://turbot.com/v5/docs/concepts/guardrails/approved) for more information.

enum: Unapproved if Budget > State is Over or higher
Unapproved if Budget > State is Critical or higher
Unapproved if Budget > State is Shutdown
example: Unapproved if Budget > State is Shutdown

applicationLoadBalancerCmdb.title: CMDB
applicationLoadBalancerCmdb.description:
Configure whether to record and synchronize details for the AWS EC2 application load balancer into the CMDB.

The [CMDB](https://turbot.com/v5/docs/concepts/guardrails/cmdb) control is responsible for populating and updating all the attributes for that resource type in the Turbot CMDB.
All policies and controls in Turbot are based around the resource, so usually the CMDB policy is set to **"Enforce: Enabled"**.

If set to Skip then all changes to the CMDB are paused - no new resources will be discovered, no updates will be made and deleted resources will not be removed.

To cleanup resources and stop tracking changes, set this policy to **"Enforce: Disabled"**.

CMDB controls also use the Regions policy associated with the resource. If region is not in `AWS > EC2 > Application Load Balancer > Regions` policy, the CMDB control will delete the resource from the CMDB.

(**Note**: Setting CMDB to **"Skip"** will also pause these changes.)

applicationLoadBalancerConfigured.title: Configured
applicationLoadBalancerConfigured.description:
Determine how to configure this resource.

**Note**: If the resource is managed by another stack, then the Skip/Check/Enforce values here are ignored
and inherit from the stack that owns it

enum: Check: Per Configured > Source (unless claimed by a stack)
Enforce: Per Configured > Source (unless claimed by a stack)

applicationLoadBalancerConfiguredSource.title: Source
applicationLoadBalancerConfiguredSource.description: A HCL or JSON format Terraform configuration source used to configure this resource

applicationLoadBalancerConfiguredPrecede.title: Claim Precedence
applicationLoadBalancerConfiguredPrecede.description:
An ordered list of who is allowed to claim a resource.
A stack cannot claim a resource if it is already claimed by another
stack at a higher level of precedence.
applicationLoadBalancerConfiguredPrecede.defaultTemplate: {%- if $.defaultPrecedence | length == 0 %}[]{%- else %}{% for item in $.defaultPrecedence %}- '{{ item }}'{% endfor %}{% endif %}

applicationLoadBalancerRegions.title: Regions
applicationLoadBalancerRegions.description:
A list of AWS regions in which AWS EC2 application load balancers are supported for use.

Any application load balancers in a region not listed here will not be recorded in CMDB.

The expected format is an array of regions names. You may use the '*' and
'?' wildcard characters.
applicationLoadBalancerRegions.defaultTemplate:
{% if $.regions.value | length == 0 %} [] {% endif %}{% for item in $.regions.value %}- '{{ item }}'
{% endfor %}

applicationLoadBalancerTags.title: Tags
applicationLoadBalancerTags.description:
Determine the action to take when an AWS EC2 application load balancer tags are not updated based on the `AWS > EC2 > Application Load Balancer > Tags > *` policies.

The control ensure AWS EC2 application load balancer tags include tags defined in `AWS > EC2 > Application Load Balancer > Tags > Template`.

Tags not defined in Application Load Balancer Tags Template will not be modified or deleted. Setting a tag value to `undefined` will result in the tag being deleted.

See [Tags](https://turbot.com/v5/docs/concepts/guardrails/tagging) for more information.

applicationLoadBalancerTagsTemplate.title: Template
applicationLoadBalancerTagsTemplate.description:
The template is used to generate the keys and values for AWS EC2 application load balancer.

Tags not defined in Application Load Balancer Tags Template will not be modified or deleted. Setting a tag value to `undefined` will result in the tag being deleted.

See [Tags](https://turbot.com/v5/docs/concepts/guardrails/tagging) for more information.
applicationLoadBalancerTagsTemplate.defaultTemplate: {%- if $.defaultTags.value | length == 0 %} [] {%- elif $.defaultTags.value != undefined %}{{ $.defaultTags.value | dump | safe }}{%- else %}{% for item in $.defaultTags.value %}- {{ item }}{% endfor %}{% endif %}

applicationLoadBalancerUsage.title: Usage
applicationLoadBalancerUsage.description:
Configure the number of AWS EC2 application load balancers that can be used for this region and the current consumption against the limit.

You can configure the behavior of the control with this  `AWS > EC2 > Application Load Balancer > Usage` policy.

applicationLoadBalancerUsageLimit.title: Limit
applicationLoadBalancerUsageLimit.description: Maximum number of items that can be created for this region.

classicLoadBalancerAccessLogging.title: Access Logging
classicLoadBalancerAccessLogging.description:
Define the Access Logging settings required for `AWS > EC2 > Classic Load Balancer`.

`AWS > EC2 > Classic Load Balancer` provides access logs that capture
detailed information about requests sent to your load
balancer. Each log contains information such as the time the
request was received, the client's IP address, latencies,
request paths, and server responses. You can use these
access logs to analyze traffic patterns and troubleshoot
issues.

enum: Check: Enabled to Access Logging > Bucket
Enforce: Enabled to Access Logging > Bucket

classicLoadBalancerAccessLoggingBucket.title: Bucket
classicLoadBalancerAccessLoggingBucket.description:
The name of an S3 Bucket to which the Bucket
access logs will be delivered.

The S3 Bucket must already exist and the S3 service must be allowed write access.
The bucket should reside in same account and same region as of the Bucket.

example:
```
  testbucket
  turbotbucket
```

classicLoadBalancerAccessLoggingKeyPrefi.title: Key Prefix
classicLoadBalancerAccessLoggingKeyPrefi.description:
An optional S3 key prefix to which the `AWS > EC2 > Classic Load Balancer` access logs will be written.

The file names of the access logs use the following format:
`bucket[/prefix]/AWSLogs/aws-account-id/elasticloadbalancing/region/yyyy/mm/dd/aws-account-id_elasticloadbalancing_region_load-balancer-id_end-time_ip-address_random-string.log.gz`

classicLoadBalancerRegions.title: Regions
classicLoadBalancerRegions.description:
A list of AWS regions in which AWS EC2 classic load balancers are supported for use.

Any classic load balancers in a region not listed here will not be recorded in CMDB.

The expected format is an array of regions names. You may use the '*' and
'?' wildcard characters.
classicLoadBalancerRegions.defaultTemplate:
{% if $.regions.value | length == 0 %} [] {% endif %}{% for item in $.regions.value %}- '{{ item }}'
{% endfor %}

classicLoadBalancerTags.title: Tags
classicLoadBalancerTags.description:
Determine the action to take when an AWS EC2 classic load balancer tags are not updated based on the `AWS > EC2 > Classic Load Balancer > Tags > *` policies.

The control ensure AWS EC2 classic load balancer tags include tags defined in `AWS > EC2 > Classic Load Balancer > Tags > Template`.

Tags not defined in Classic Load Balancer Tags Template will not be modified or deleted. Setting a tag value to `undefined` will result in the tag being deleted.

See [Tags](https://turbot.com/v5/docs/concepts/guardrails/tagging) for more information.

classicLoadBalancerTagsTemplate.title: Template
classicLoadBalancerTagsTemplate.description:
The template is used to generate the keys and values for AWS EC2 classic load balancer.

Tags not defined in Classic Load Balancer Tags Template will not be modified or deleted. Setting a tag value to `undefined` will result in the tag being deleted.

See [Tags](https://turbot.com/v5/docs/concepts/guardrails/tagging) for more information.
classicLoadBalancerTagsTemplate.defaultTemplate: {%- if $.defaultTags.value | length == 0 %} [] {%- elif $.defaultTags.value != undefined %}{{ $.defaultTags.value | dump | safe }}{%- else %}{% for item in $.defaultTags.value %}- {{ item }}{% endfor %}{% endif %}

classicLoadBalancerUsage.title: Usage
classicLoadBalancerUsage.description:
Configure the number of AWS EC2 classic load balancers that can be used for this region and the current consumption against the limit.

You can configure the behavior of the control with this  `AWS > EC2 > Classic Load Balancer > Usage` policy.

classicLoadBalancerUsageLimit.title: Limit
classicLoadBalancerUsageLimit.description: Maximum number of items that can be created for this region.

ec2CustomEventPatterns.title: @turbot/aws-ec2
ec2CustomEventPatterns.description:
The CloudWatch Events event pattern used by the AWS EC2 module to specify
which events to forward to the Turbot Event Handlers.

ec2ApiEnabled.title: API Enabled
ec2ApiEnabled.description:
Configure whether the AWS EC2 API is enabled.

**Note:** Disabling the service disables the API for ALL users
and roles, and Turbot will have no access to the API.

ec2Permissions.title: Permissions
ec2Permissions.description:
Configure whether permissions policies are in effect for AWS EC2.
This setting does not affect account level permissions (AWS/Admin, AWS/Owner, etc).

**Note**: The behavior of this policy depends on the value of AWS > Permissions.

enum: Enabled if AWS > EC2 > Enabled & AWS > EC2 > API Enabled
schema.default: Enabled if AWS > EC2 > Enabled & AWS > EC2 > API Enabled

ec2PermissionsLockdownApiBoundary.title: API Boundary
ec2PermissionsLockdownApiBoundary.description:
Configure whether the AWS ec2 API is enabled for all
users and roles in turbot-managed boundary policies.

**Note:** Disabling the service disables the API for ALL users
and roles, and Turbot will have no access to the API.

enum: Enabled if AWS > EC2 > API Enabled
example: Enabled if AWS > EC2 > API Enabled
schema.default: Enabled if AWS > EC2 > API Enabled

ec2PermissionsLockdownInstanceTypes.title: Instance Types
ec2PermissionsLockdownInstanceTypes.description:
Configure whether lockdown policies are enabled to prohibit modification of Instance Types.

**Note:** It is recommended to include instance types from all `AWS > EC2 > Instance > Approved > Instance Types` policy settings to ensure that this lockdown policy will not restrict any approved instance types.

Example:
```
  - t2.micro
  - t2.small
  - d2.xlarge
```

ec2PermissionsLockdownVolumeTypes.title: Volume Types
ec2PermissionsLockdownVolumeTypes.description:
Configure whether lockdown policies are enabled to prohibit modification of Volume Types.

**Note:** It is recommended to include volume types from all `AWS > EC2 > Volume > Approved > Volume Types` policy settings to ensure that this lockdown policy will not restrict any approved volume types.

Example:
```
  - sc1
  - standard
  - gp2
```

ec2PermissionsLevels.title: Levels
ec2PermissionsLevels.description:
Define the permissions levels that can be used to grant access to an AWS account.
Permissions levels defined will appear in the UI to assign access to Turbot users.
This policy provides a default for Permissions > Levels in each service, however
you can explicitly override the setting for each service if desired
ec2PermissionsLevels.defaultTemplate:
{% if $.availableLevels.items[0].value | length == 0 %} [] {% endif %}{% for item in $.availableLevels.items[0].value %}- {{ item }}
{% endfor %}

ec2PermissionsLevelsModifiers.title: Modifiers
ec2PermissionsLevelsModifiers.description:
A map of AWS API to Turbot Permission Level used to customize Turbot's standard permissions.
You can add, remove or redefine the mapping of AWS API operations to Turbot permissions levels here.

**Note:** Modifiers are cumulative - if you add a permission to the Metadata level, it is also
added to ReadOnly, Operator and Admin. Modifier policies set here apply ONLY to the AWS level.

```
example:
  - "glacier:createvault": admin
  - "glacier:ListVaults": metadata
  - "s3:DeleteBucket": none
```

ec2PermissionsLevelsAutoScalingAdministr.title: Auto Scaling Administration
ec2PermissionsLevelsAutoScalingAdministr.description: Determines which Turbot permissions level can manage Auto Scaling Administration.

ec2PermissionsLevelsAmiPublishingAdminis.title: Ami Publishing Administration
ec2PermissionsLevelsAmiPublishingAdminis.description: Determines which Turbot permissions level can manage AMI Publishing Administration.

ec2PermissionsLevelsMarketplaceSubscript.title: Marketplace Subscription Administration
ec2PermissionsLevelsMarketplaceSubscript.description: Determines which Turbot permissions level can manage Marketplace Subscription Administration.

ec2PermissionsLevelsLocalAmisAdministrat.title: Local Amis Administration
ec2PermissionsLevelsLocalAmisAdministrat.description: Determines which Turbot permissions level can manage Local AMIs Administration.

awsCompiledServicePermissions.title: @turbot/aws-ec2
awsCompiledServicePermissions.description:
A calculated policy that Turbot uses to create a compiled
list of ALL permissions for AWS EC2 that is used as input
to the control that manages the IAM stack.

awsCompiledLockdownStatements.title: @turbot/aws-ec2
awsCompiledLockdownStatements.description:
A calculated policy that Turbot uses to create a compiled list
of ALL lockdown policy statements for AWS EC2 that is used as
input to the stack that manages the Turbot IAM permissions objects.

awsLevelsCompiled.title: @turbot/aws-ec2
awsLevelsCompiled.description:
A calculated policy that Turbot uses to create a compiled
list of ALL permissions for AWS EC2 that is used as input to
the stack that manages the Turbot IAM permissions objects.

awsCompiledApiBoundary.title: @turbot/aws-ec2
awsCompiledApiBoundary.description:
A read-only policy generated by Turbot that lists the APIs that
should be added to the turbot-managed (hard) boundary policy,
thereby enabling them to be assigned to users and roles.
This value will change depending on the value of the value of the
`AWS > EC2 > Permissions > Lockdown > API Boundary` policy

ec2RegionsDefault.title: Regions
ec2RegionsDefault.description:
A list of AWS regions in which AWS EC2 resources are supported for use.

The expected format is an array of regions names. You may use the '*' and
'?' wildcard characters.

This policy is the default value for all AWS EC2 resources' Regions policies.
ec2RegionsDefault.defaultTemplate:
{% if $.regions.value | length == 0 %} [] {% endif %}{% for item in $.regions.value %}- '{{ item }}'
{% endfor %}

ec2ApprovedRegionsDefault.title: Approved Regions [Default]
ec2ApprovedRegionsDefault.description:
A list of AWS regions in which AWS EC2 resources are approved for use.

The expected format is an array of regions names. You may use the '*' and
'?' wildcard characters.

This policy is the default value for all AWS EC2 resources' Approved > Regions policies.
ec2ApprovedRegionsDefault.defaultTemplate:
{% if $.regions.value | length == 0 %} [] {% endif %}{% for item in $.regions.value %}- '{{ item }}'
{% endfor %}

ec2TagsTemplate.title: Tags Template [Default]
ec2TagsTemplate.description:
A template used to generate the keys and values for AWS EC2 resources.

By default, all EC2 resource Tags > Template policies will use this value.
ec2TagsTemplate.defaultTemplate: {%- if $.defaultTags.value | length == 0 %} [] {%- elif $.defaultTags.value != undefined %}{{ $.defaultTags.value | dump | safe }}{%- else %}{% for item in $.defaultTags.value %}- {{ item }}{% endfor %}{% endif %}

ec2TrustedAccounts.title: Trusted Accounts [Default]
ec2TrustedAccounts.description:
List of AWS Accounts that are trusted for access in the AWS EC2 policy.

This policy is used by the Trusted Access
control to determine which members of type "account" are allowed
to be granted access. You may use the '*' and '?' wildcard characters.

```
example:
  - "013122550996"
  - "560741234067"
```

**Note**: Setting the policy to `Empty` array will remove all accounts.
ec2TrustedAccounts.defaultTemplate:
{% if $.trustedAccounts.value | length == 0 %}[]{% else %}{% for item in $.trustedAccounts.value %}- '{{ item }}'
{% endfor %}{% endif %}

instanceActive.title: Active
instanceActive.description:
Determine the action to take when an AWS EC2 instance, based on the `AWS > EC2 > Instance > Active > *` policies.

The control determines whether the resource is in active use, and if not,
has the ability to delete / cleanup the resource. When running an automated
compliance environment, it's common to end up with a wide range of alarms
that are difficult and time consuming to clear. The Active control brings
automated, well-defined control to this process.

The Active control checks the status of all defined Active policies for the
resource (`AWS > EC2 > Instance > Active > *`), raises an alarm, and takes the defined enforcement
action. Each Active sub-policy can calculate a status of active, inactive
or skipped. Generally, if the resource appears to be Active for any reason
it will be considered Active.
**Note** the contrast with Approved, where if the resource appears to be Unapproved for any reason it will be considered
Unapproved.

See [Active](https://turbot.com/v5/docs/concepts/guardrails/active) for more information.

enum: Enforce: Delete inactive with 1 day warning
Enforce: Delete inactive with 3 days warning
Enforce: Delete inactive with 7 days warning
Enforce: Delete inactive with 14 days warning
Enforce: Delete inactive with 30 days warning
Enforce: Delete inactive with 60 days warning
Enforce: Delete inactive with 90 days warning
Enforce: Delete inactive with 180 days warning
Enforce: Delete inactive with 365 days warning

instanceActiveLastModified.title: Last Modified
instanceActiveLastModified.description:
The number of days since the AWS EC2 instance
was last modified before it is considered inactive.

The [Active](https://turbot.com/v5/docs/concepts/guardrails/active)
control determines whether the resource is in active use, and if not, has
the ability to delete / cleanup the resource. When running an automated
compliance environment, it's common to end up with a wide range of alarms
that are difficult and time consuming to clear. The Active control brings
automated, well-defined control to this process.

The Active control checks the status of all defined Active policies for the
resource (`AWS > EC2 > Instance > Active > *`),
raises an alarm, and takes the defined enforcement action. Each Active
sub-policy can calculate a status of active, inactive or skipped. Generally,
if the resource appears to be Active for any reason it will be considered Active.
**Note** the contrast with Approved, where if the resource appears to be Unapproved
for any reason it will be considered Unapproved.

See [Active](https://turbot.com/v5/docs/concepts/guardrails/active) for more information.

enum: Force active if last modified <= 1 day
Force active if last modified <= 3 days
Force active if last modified <= 7 days
Force active if last modified <= 14 days
Force active if last modified <= 30 days
Force active if last modified <= 60 days
Force active if last modified <= 90 days
Force active if last modified <= 180 days
Force active if last modified <= 365 days

instanceActiveAge.title: Age
instanceActiveAge.description:
The age after which the AWS EC2 instance
is no longer considered active. If a create time is unavailable, the time Turbot discovered the resource is used.

The [Active](https://turbot.com/v5/docs/concepts/guardrails/active)
control determines whether the resource is in active use, and if not, has
the ability to delete / cleanup the resource. When running an automated
compliance environment, it's common to end up with a wide range of alarms
that are difficult and time consuming to clear. The Active control brings
automated, well-defined control to this process.

The Active control checks the status of all defined Active policies for the
resource (`AWS > EC2 > Instance > Active > *`),
raises an alarm, and takes the defined enforcement action. Each Active
sub-policy can calculate a status of active, inactive or skipped. Generally,
if the resource appears to be Active for any reason it will be considered Active.
**Note** the contrast with Approved, where if the resource appears to be Unapproved
for any reason it will be considered Unapproved.

See [Active](https://turbot.com/v5/docs/concepts/guardrails/active) for more information.

instanceActiveBudget.title: Budget
instanceActiveBudget.description:
The impact of the budget state on the active control. This policy allows you to force
instances to inactive based on the current budget state, as reflected in
`AWS > Account > Budget > State`

The Active control determines whether the resource is in active use, and if not, has
the ability to delete / cleanup the resource. When running an automated compliance
environment, it's common to end up with a wide range of alarms that are difficult
and time consuming to clear. The Active control brings automated, well-defined
control to this process.

The Active control checks the status of all defined Active policies for the
resource (`AWS > EC2 > Instance > Active > *`),
raises an alarm, and takes the defined enforcement action. Each Active
sub-policy can calculate a status of active, inactive or skipped. Generally,
if the resource appears to be Active for any reason it will be considered Active.
**Note** the contrast with Approved, where if the resource appears to be Unapproved
for any reason it will be considered Unapproved.

See [Active](https://turbot.com/v5/docs/concepts/guardrails/active) for more information.

enum: Force inactive if Budget > State is Over or higher
Force inactive if Budget > State is Critical or higher
Force inactive if Budget > State is Shutdown

instanceApproved.title: Approved
instanceApproved.description:
Determine the action to take when an AWS EC2 instance is not approved based on `AWS > EC2 > Instance > Approved > *` policies.

The Approved control checks the status of the defined Approved sub-policies for the resource. If the resource is not approved according to any of these policies, this control raises an alarm and takes the defined enforcement action.

For any enforcement actions that specify `if new`, e.g., `Enforce: Delete unapproved if new`, this control will only take the enforcement actions for resources created within the last 60 minutes.

See [Approved](https://turbot.com/v5/docs/concepts/guardrails/approved) for more information.

instanceApprovedRegions.title: Regions
instanceApprovedRegions.description:
A list of AWS regions in which AWS EC2 instances are approved for use.

The expected format is an array of regions names. You may use the '*' and '?' wildcard characters.

This policy will be evaluated by the Approved control. If an AWS EC2 instance is created in a region that is not in the approved list, it will be subject to the action specified in the `AWS > EC2 > Instance > Approved` policy.

See [Approved](https://turbot.com/v5/docs/concepts/guardrails/approved) for more information.
instanceApprovedRegions.defaultTemplate:
{% if $.regions | length == 0 %} [] {% endif %}{% for item in $.regions %}- '{{ item }}'
{% endfor %}

instanceApprovedUsage.title: Usage
instanceApprovedUsage.description:
Determine whether the AWS EC2 instance is allowed to exist.

This policy will be evaluated by the Approved control. If an AWS EC2 instance is not approved, it will be subject to the action specified in the `AWS > EC2 > Instance > Approved` policy.

See [Approved](https://turbot.com/v5/docs/concepts/guardrails/approved) for more information.

instanceApprovedBudget.title: Budget
instanceApprovedBudget.description:
The policy allows you to set instances to unapproved based on the current budget state, as reflected in `AWS > Account > Budget > State`

This policy will be evaluated by the Approved control. If an AWS EC2 instance is not matched by the approved list, it will be subject to the action specified in the `AWS > EC2 > Instance > Approved` policy.

See [Approved](https://turbot.com/v5/docs/concepts/guardrails/approved) for more information.

enum: Unapproved if Budget > State is Over or higher
Unapproved if Budget > State is Critical or higher
Unapproved if Budget > State is Shutdown
example: Unapproved if Budget > State is Shutdown

instanceApprovedInstanceTypes.title: Instance Types
instanceApprovedInstanceTypes.description:
A list of instance types that the AWS EC2 instance is approved to use.

The expected format is an array of instance types. You may use the `*` and `?` wildcard characters (and [more](https://github.com/micromatch/micromatch#matching-features)).

This policy will be evaluated by the Approved control. If an AWS EC2 instance is not matched by the approved list, it will be subject to the action specified in the `AWS > EC2 > Instance > Approved` policy.

See [Approved](https://turbot.com/v5/docs/concepts/guardrails/approved) for more information.

**Note:** It is recommended to include instance types in this policy in the `AWS > EC2 > Permissions > Lockdown > Instance Types` policy as well, to ensure that the lockdown policy will not restrict these approved instance types.

instanceApprovedPublicIp.title: Public IP
instanceApprovedPublicIp.description:
Determine whether the AWS EC2 instance is allowed to have a Public IP assigned.

This policy will be evaluated by the Approved control. If an AWS EC2 instance is not approved, it will be subject to the action specified in the `AWS > EC2 > Instance > Approved` policy.

See [Approved](https://turbot.com/v5/docs/concepts/guardrails/approved) for more information.

rootVolumeEncryptionAtRest.title: Root Volume Encryption at Rest
rootVolumeEncryptionAtRest.description:
Define the Encryption at Rest settings required for `AWS > EC2 > Instance.

Encryption at Rest refers specifically to the encryption of data when written
to an underlying storage system. This control determines whether the resource
is encrypted at rest, and sets encryption to your desired level.

The [Encryption at Rest](https://turbot.com/v5/docs/concepts/guardrails/encryption-at-rest)
control compares the encryption settings against the encryption policies for the resource
(AWS > EC2 > Instance > Approved > Root Volume Encryption at Rest > *),
raises an alarm, and takes the defined enforcement action

enum: Encryption at Rest > Customer Managed Key

rootVolumeEncryptionAtRestCustomerManage.title: Customer Managed Key
rootVolumeEncryptionAtRestCustomerManage.description:
Define the KMS key ID for encryption at rest.

Encryption at Rest refers specifically to the encryption of data when written
to an underlying storage system. This control determines whether the resource
is encrypted at rest, and sets encryption to your desired level.

The [Encryption at Rest](https://turbot.com/v5/docs/concepts/guardrails/encryption-at-rest)
control compares the encryption settings against the encryption policies for the resource
(AWS > EC2 > Instance > Root Volume Encryption at Rest  > *),
raises an alarm, and takes the defined enforcement action

Please make sure the key defined in the template has required permissions.

```
example:
  alias/aws/ebs
  ddc06e04-ce5f-4995-c758-c2b6c510e8fd
  arn:aws:kms:us-east-1:123456789012:key/ddc06e04-ce5f-4995-c758-c2b6c510e8fd
  arn:aws:kms:us-east-1:123456789012:alias/aws/ebs
```

instanceApprovedImage.title: Image
instanceApprovedImage.description: Determine whether Approved > Image checking is enable for the instance

enum: Approved if ImageId in Image > AMI IDs
Approved if Owner in Image > Publishers
Approved if ImageId in Image > AMI IDs or Owner in Image > Publishers
Approved if ImageId in Image > AMI IDs and Owner in Image > Publishers

instanceApprovedImageAmiIds.title: AMI IDs
instanceApprovedImageAmiIds.description:
A list of AMI IDs that are approved to be used to launch EC2 Instances.

The '*' wildcard may be used to allow all AMIs

Examples:
    - ami-ff81a385
    - ami-12345678

instanceApprovedImagePublishers.title: Publishers
instanceApprovedImagePublishers.description:
A list of AWS Account ids who's images may be used to launch EC2 Instances.  This list may contain:
  - AWS Account IDs - Approve all images from the specified account
  - `local` - Approve local images (where the `OwnerId` is the account id of the targeted instance)
  - `amazon` - Approve amazon images (where imageowneralias == `amazon`)
  - `aws-marketplace`  - Approve marketplace images (where imageowneralias == `aws-marketplace`)

The '*' wildcard may be used to allow all AMIs from all publishers.

  Examples:
     - amazon         # allow all images with `amazon` ImageOwnerAlias
     - 102837901569   # Allow all images from AWS Account 102837901569
     - local          # Allow all local images

instanceCmdb.title: CMDB
instanceCmdb.description:
Configure whether to record and synchronize details for the AWS EC2 instance into the CMDB.

The [CMDB](https://turbot.com/v5/docs/concepts/guardrails/cmdb) control is responsible for populating and updating all the attributes for that resource type in the Turbot CMDB.
All policies and controls in Turbot are based around the resource, so usually the CMDB policy is set to **"Enforce: Enabled"**.

If set to Skip then all changes to the CMDB are paused - no new resources will be discovered, no updates will be made and deleted resources will not be removed.

To cleanup resources and stop tracking changes, set this policy to **"Enforce: Disabled"**.

CMDB controls also use the Regions policy associated with the resource. If region is not in `AWS > EC2 > Instance > Regions` policy, the CMDB control will delete the resource from the CMDB.

(**Note**: Setting CMDB to **"Skip"** will also pause these changes.)

instanceCmdbAttributes.title: Attributes
instanceCmdbAttributes.description:
A list of attributes to retrieve data for in the CMDB control.

Any properties that are enabled and then later disabled will be removed and no longer tracked for this resource.

instanceConfigured.title: Configured
instanceConfigured.description:
Determine how to configure this resource.

**Note**: If the resource is managed by another stack, then the Skip/Check/Enforce values here are ignored
and inherit from the stack that owns it

enum: Check: Per Configured > Source (unless claimed by a stack)
Enforce: Per Configured > Source (unless claimed by a stack)

instanceConfiguredSource.title: Source
instanceConfiguredSource.description: A HCL or JSON format Terraform configuration source used to configure this resource

instanceConfiguredPrecedence.title: Claim Precedence
instanceConfiguredPrecedence.description:
An ordered list of who is allowed to claim a resource.
A stack cannot claim a resource if it is already claimed by another
stack at a higher level of precedence.
instanceConfiguredPrecedence.defaultTemplate: {%- if $.defaultPrecedence | length == 0 %}[]{%- else %}{% for item in $.defaultPrecedence %}- '{{ item }}'{% endfor %}{% endif %}

instanceDetailedMonitoring.title: Detailed Monitoring
instanceDetailedMonitoring.description:
Define the Detailed Monitoring settings required for `AWS > EC2 > Instance > Detailed Monitoring`.

If detailed monitoring is enabled then Amazon EC2 console displays monitoring graphs with a 1-minute period for the instance.

**Note**: Enabling detailed monitoring will incur additional charges.

instanceProfile.title: Instance Profile
instanceProfile.description: Determine whether the IAM instance profile is attached to AWS > EC2 > Instance.

instanceProfileName.title: Name
instanceProfileName.description: The IAM instance profile name to be attached to the AWS EC2 instance.

instanceMetadataService.title: Metadata Service
instanceMetadataService.description:
Instance metadata is data about your instance that you can use to configure or manage the running instance.
Instance metadata is divided into categories, for example, host name, events, and security groups.

Instance metadata can be accessed from a running instance using one of the following methods:

  * Instance Metadata Service Version 1 (IMDSv1)  a request/response method

  * Instance Metadata Service Version 2 (IMDSv2)  a session-oriented method

By default, you can use either IMDSv1 or IMDSv2, or both. However, the instance metadata service can be specifically
configured to use IMDSv2 on each instance. When you specify that IMDSv2 must be used, IMDSv1 no longer works.

enum: Check: Enabled for V1 and V2
Enforce: Enabled for V1 and V2

instanceMetadataServiceTokenHopLimit.title: HTTP Token Hop Limit
instanceMetadataServiceTokenHopLimit.description:
The number of network hops that the metadata token can travel.

The larger the number, the further instance metadata requests can travel.

Maximum is 64.

instanceRegions.title: Regions
instanceRegions.description:
A list of AWS regions in which AWS EC2 instances are supported for use.

Any instances in a region not listed here will not be recorded in CMDB.

The expected format is an array of regions names. You may use the '*' and
'?' wildcard characters.
instanceRegions.defaultTemplate:
{% if $.regions.value | length == 0 %} [] {% endif %}{% for item in $.regions.value %}- '{{ item }}'
{% endfor %}

instanceSchedule.title: Schedule
instanceSchedule.description:
Set a schedule for starting and stopping an AWS EC2 instance.

**Note** If both "Schedule" and "Schedule Tag" are set to enforce and the
the tag will be in effect.

enum: Enforce: Extended business hours (7:00am - 11:00pm on weekdays)
Enforce: Stop for night (stop at 10:00pm every day)
Enforce: Stop for weekend (stop at 10:00pm on Friday)

instanceScheduleTag.title: Schedule Tag
instanceScheduleTag.description:
Allow setting a schedule for starting and stopping an EC2 instance via the
turbot_custom_schedule tag. If the schedule is invalid, no actions will be
taken against the instance.

**Note** If both "Schedule" and "Schedule Tag" are set to enforce and the
instance has a turbot_custom_schedule, then the schedule specified by the
tag will be in effect.

instanceTags.title: Tags
instanceTags.description:
Determine the action to take when an AWS EC2 instance tags are not updated based on the `AWS > EC2 > Instance > Tags > *` policies.

The control ensure AWS EC2 instance tags include tags defined in `AWS > EC2 > Instance > Tags > Template`.

Tags not defined in Instance Tags Template will not be modified or deleted. Setting a tag value to `undefined` will result in the tag being deleted.

See [Tags](https://turbot.com/v5/docs/concepts/guardrails/tagging) for more information.

instanceTagsInventoryCollection.title: Inventory Collection
instanceTagsInventoryCollection.description: Configuring AWS > EC2 > Instance with default SSM inventory collection instance tags.

instanceTagsTemplate.title: Template
instanceTagsTemplate.description:
The template is used to generate the keys and values for AWS EC2 instance.

Tags not defined in Instance Tags Template will not be modified or deleted. Setting a tag value to `undefined` will result in the tag being deleted.

See [Tags](https://turbot.com/v5/docs/concepts/guardrails/tagging) for more information.
instanceTagsTemplate.defaultTemplate: {%- if $.defaultTags.value | length == 0 %} [] {%- elif $.defaultTags.value != undefined %}{{ $.defaultTags.value | dump | safe }}{%- else %}{% for item in $.defaultTags.value %}- {{ item }}{% endfor %}{% endif %}

instanceTerminationProtection.title: Termination Protection
instanceTerminationProtection.description:
Define the Termination Protection settings required for `AWS > EC2 > Instance > Termination Protection`.

It allows to prevent an instance from being terminated accidentally by someone using the AWS Management Console, the CLI, and the API.

instanceUsage.title: Usage
instanceUsage.description:
Configure the number of AWS EC2 instances that can be used for this region and the current consumption against the limit.

You can configure the behavior of the control with this  `AWS > EC2 > Instance > Usage` policy.

instanceUsageLimit.title: Limit
instanceUsageLimit.description: Maximum number of items that can be created for this region.

keyPairActive.title: Active
keyPairActive.description:
Determine the action to take when an AWS EC2 key pair, based on the `AWS > EC2 > Key Pair > Active > *` policies.

The control determines whether the resource is in active use, and if not,
has the ability to delete / cleanup the resource. When running an automated
compliance environment, it's common to end up with a wide range of alarms
that are difficult and time consuming to clear. The Active control brings

keyPairApproved.title: Approved
keyPairApproved.description:
Determine the action to take when an AWS EC2 key pair is not approved based on `AWS > EC2 > Key Pair > Approved > *` policies.

The Approved control checks the status of the defined Approved sub-policies for the resource. If the resource is not approved according to any of these policies, this control raises an alarm and takes the defined enforcement action.

For any enforcement actions that specify `if new`, e.g., `Enforce: Delete unapproved if new`, this control will only take the enforcement actions for resources created within the last 60 minutes.

See [Approved](https://turbot.com/v5/docs/concepts/guardrails/approved) for more information.

keyPairApprovedRegions.title: Regions
keyPairApprovedRegions.description:
A list of AWS regions in which AWS EC2 key pairs are approved for use.

The expected format is an array of regions names. You may use the '*' and '?' wildcard characters.

This policy will be evaluated by the Approved control. If an AWS EC2 key pair is created in a region that is not in the approved list, it will be subject to the action specified in the `AWS > EC2 > Key Pair > Approved` policy.

See [Approved](https://turbot.com/v5/docs/concepts/guardrails/approved) for more information.
keyPairApprovedRegions.defaultTemplate:
{% if $.regions | length == 0 %} [] {% endif %}{% for item in $.regions %}- '{{ item }}'
{% endfor %}

keyPairApprovedUsage.title: Usage
keyPairApprovedUsage.description:
Determine whether the AWS EC2 key pair is allowed to exist.

This policy will be evaluated by the Approved control. If an AWS EC2 key pair is not approved, it will be subject to the action specified in the `AWS > EC2 > Key Pair > Approved` policy.

See [Approved](https://turbot.com/v5/docs/concepts/guardrails/approved) for more information.

keyPairApprovedBudget.title: Budget
keyPairApprovedBudget.description:
The policy allows you to set key pairs to unapproved based on the current budget state, as reflected in `AWS > Account > Budget > State`

This policy will be evaluated by the Approved control. If an AWS EC2 key pair is not matched by the approved list, it will be subject to the action specified in the `AWS > EC2 > Key Pair > Approved` policy.

See [Approved](https://turbot.com/v5/docs/concepts/guardrails/approved) for more information.

enum: Unapproved if Budget > State is Over or higher
Unapproved if Budget > State is Critical or higher
Unapproved if Budget > State is Shutdown
example: Unapproved if Budget > State is Shutdown

keyPairCmdb.title: CMDB
keyPairCmdb.description:
Configure whether to record and synchronize details for the AWS EC2 key pair into the CMDB.

The [CMDB](https://turbot.com/docs/concepts/guardrails/cmdb) control is responsible for populating and updating all the attributes for that resource type in the Turbot CMDB. All policies and controls in Turbot are based around the resource, so usually the CMDB policy is set to "Enforce: Enabled".

If set to Skip then all changes to the CMDB are paused - no new resources will be discovered, no updates will be made and deleted resources will not be removed.

To cleanup resources and stop tracking changes, set this policy to "Enforce: Disabled".

keyPairRegions.title: Regions
keyPairRegions.description:
A list of AWS regions in which AWS EC2 key pairs are supported for use.

Any key pairs in a region not listed here will not be recorded in CMDB.

The expected format is an array of regions names. You may use the '*' and
'?' wildcard characters.
keyPairRegions.defaultTemplate:
{% if $.regions.value | length == 0 %} [] {% endif %}{% for item in $.regions.value %}- '{{ item }}'
{% endfor %}

keyPairTags.title: Tags
keyPairTags.description:
Determine the action to take when an AWS EC2 key pair tags are not updated based on the `AWS > EC2 > Key Pair > Tags > *` policies.

The control ensure AWS EC2 key pair tags include tags defined in `AWS > EC2 > Key Pair > Tags > Template`.

Tags not defined in Key Pair Tags Template will not be modified or deleted. Setting a tag value to `undefined` will result in the tag being deleted.

See [Tags](https://turbot.com/v5/docs/concepts/guardrails/tagging) for more information.

keyPairTagsTemplate.title: Template
keyPairTagsTemplate.description:
The template is used to generate the keys and values for AWS EC2 key pair.

Tags not defined in Key Pair Tags Template will not be modified or deleted. Setting a tag value to `undefined` will result in the tag being deleted.

See [Tags](https://turbot.com/v5/docs/concepts/guardrails/tagging) for more information.
keyPairTagsTemplate.defaultTemplate: {%- if $.defaultTags.value | length == 0 %} [] {%- elif $.defaultTags.value != undefined %}{{ $.defaultTags.value | dump | safe }}{%- else %}{% for item in $.defaultTags.value %}- {{ item }}{% endfor %}{% endif %}

keyPairUsage.title: Usage
keyPairUsage.description:
Configure the number of AWS EC2 key pairs that can be used for this region and the current consumption against the limit.

You can configure the behavior of the control with this  `AWS > EC2 > Key Pair > Usage` policy.

keyPairUsageLimit.title: Limit
keyPairUsageLimit.description: Maximum number of items that can be created for this region.

launchTemplateVersionApprovedRegions.defaultTemplate:
{% if $.regions | length == 0 %} [] {% endif %}{% for item in $.regions %}- '{{ item }}'
{% endfor %}

launchTemplateVersionCmdb.title: CMDB

The [CMDB](https://turbot.com/v5/docs/concepts/guardrails/cmdb) control is responsible for populating and updating all the attributes for that resource type in the Turbot CMDB.
All policies and controls in Turbot are based around the resource, so usually the CMDB policy is set to **"Enforce: Enabled"**.

If set to Skip then all changes to the CMDB are paused - no new resources will be discovered, no updates will be made and deleted resources will not be removed.

To cleanup resources and stop tracking changes, set this policy to **"Enforce: Disabled"**.

networkLoadBalancerAccessLogging.title: Access Logging
networkLoadBalancerAccessLogging.description:
Define the Access Logging settings required for `AWS > EC2 > Network Load Balancer`.

`AWS > EC2 > Network Load Balancer` provides access logs that capture
detailed information about requests sent to your load
balancer. Each log contains information such as the time the
request was received, the client's IP address, latencies,
request paths, and server responses. You can use these
access logs to analyze traffic patterns and troubleshoot
issues.

enum: Check: Enabled to Access Logging > Bucket
Enforce: Enabled to Access Logging > Bucket

networkLoadBalancerAccessLoggingBucket.title: Bucket
networkLoadBalancerAccessLoggingBucket.description:
The name of an S3 Bucket to which the Bucket
access logs will be delivered.

The S3 Bucket must already exist and the S3 service must be allowed write access.
The bucket can reside in any account but must be in the same region as the Load Balancer.

example:
```
  testbucket
  turbotbucket
```

networkLoadBalancerAccessLoggingKeyPrefi.title: Key Prefix
networkLoadBalancerAccessLoggingKeyPrefi.description:
An optional S3 key prefix to which the `AWS > EC2 > Network Load Balancer` access logs will be written.

The file names of the access logs use the following format:
`bucket[/prefix]/AWSLogs/aws-account-id/elasticloadbalancing/region/yyyy/mm/dd/aws-account-id_elasticloadbalancing_region_load-balancer-id_end-time_ip-address_random-string.log.gz`

snapshotActiveLastModified.title: Last Modified
snapshotActiveLastModified.description:
The number of days since the AWS EC2 snapshot
was last modified before it is considered inactive.

The [Active](https://turbot.com/v5/docs/concepts/guardrails/active)
control determines whether the resource is in active use, and if not, has
the ability to delete / cleanup the resource. When running an automated
compliance environment, it's common to end up with a wide range of alarms
that are difficult and time consuming to clear. The Active control brings
automated, well-defined control to this process.

The Active control checks the status of all defined Active policies for the
resource (`AWS > EC2 > Snapshot > Active > *`),
raises an alarm, and takes the defined enforcement action. Each Active
sub-policy can calculate a status of active, inactive or skipped. Generally,
if the resource appears to be Active for any reason it will be considered Active.
**Note** the contrast with Approved, where if the resource appears to be Unapproved
for any reason it will be considered Unapproved.

See [Active](https://turbot.com/v5/docs/concepts/guardrails/active) for more information.

enum: Force active if last modified <= 1 day
Force active if last modified <= 3 days
Force active if last modified <= 7 days
Force active if last modified <= 14 days
Force active if last modified <= 30 days
Force active if last modified <= 60 days
Force active if last modified <= 90 days
Force active if last modified <= 180 days
Force active if last modified <= 365 days
